Description: Mould-made pottery lamp with a rectangular body: six wick-holes along front edge, two on each short side. Tendrils at rear corners, comic masks at front corners. The handle is in the form of a reclining lion. The scene on top is of a a healing shrine, perhaps the Serapeum at Canopus; near the centre, a dwarf-like naked man stands at the door of a building, reached by a flight of steps. The building has a pediment, supported by two lotus columns; in its side wall are two semi-circular windows. The doorman greets a heavily draped woman, who is accompanied by a slave carrying a child. Behind the slave two draped figures are shown close together; one is possibly carrying the other. Nearby is an altar, with horned corners and columns below, and it has relief figures on the sides. On the left of the scene, a figure leans out of one of the windows; below, a saddled horse is grazing, behind which is a man in a short tunic, who stands shading his eyes with his right hand. Rectangular raised base. Brown clay with mica covered with red-brown slip on upper side. Plaster mould.
Curator's comments: The scene depicted on this lamp is discussed in Bailey, D.M., 1988. 'A Catalogue of the Lamps in the British Museum, III: Roman Provincial Lamps'. London : British Museum Press, p.48-49.
Compare a lamp from the L. Benaki Collection in Alexandria, Inv. No. 29154, which has the same shape and detail (handle, corner decorations, etc.), but with two swags decorating the top.
